---
title: 'Tablets in two Norwegian primary schools: is it time to consider young pupils’
  framings of using tablets in education?'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-4WV4BXEP" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Bjørgen, A. M. (2022). Tablets in two Norwegian primary schools: is it time to consider young pupils’ framings of using tablets in education? <i>Education 3-13</i>, <i>50</i>(7), 954–965. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1080/03004279.2021.1929376">https://doi.org/10.1080/03004279.2021.1929376</a></div> </div>

<div id="csl-bib-meta-4WV4BXEP" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-4WV4BXEP" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Bjørgen conducted a study in two Norwegian primary schools to understand how students aged 9-13 perceive using tablets in their education. Through group interviews, they found that students view tablet activities as engaging and fun, but also challenging and heavily guided by teachers. Students often focus on what they think is important to their teachers, which can sometimes disrupt the learning process. This study highlights the need to consider how students' views on digital activities interact with traditional school practices. Understanding this can help improve how digital tools are used in schools, ensuring they enhance learning and help students develop important digital skills. This research is important as it can guide educators in effectively integrating technology into classrooms.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-4WV4BXEP" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Tablets, Primary Schools, Pupils, Digital Competences, Teacher Facilitation, Digital Literacy Practices
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-4WV4BXEP" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    This article investigates how 9–13 years old pupils interpret activities involving the use of tablets in two Norwegian primary schools. The theoretical context draws on Goffman’s frame analysis and on research on young people’s digital literacy practices as socially situated meaning-making practices. Data was gathered through group interviews. The findings show that pupils framed activities involving tablets as engaging, enabling and playful, but also as teacher-directed and as challenging to their existing competences. Pupils’ framings were largely defined by what they expected to be of importance to their teachers but sometimes these also interrupted the teacher’s facilitation. The outcomes allow us to discuss the implications for pupils in developing digital competences, as a result of participation in a variety of digital practices. The article underscores the importance of considering the interplay between pupils’ framings of digital activities and the established conventions in the school context.
  </article>
